reasoning: Cruciality is high because whether irreversible lock-in precedes mature reflection/bargaining is a major fork: it would shift emphasis from cultivating convergence/markets for moral trade to early governance, constraint-setting, and anti-lock-in institutions. Paper-specificity is fairly high: the paper repeatedly relies on ‘reasonably good conditions’ and explicitly flags early lock-in as a key blocker that would undercut both WAM-convergence and trade-based routes; however, ‘lock-in mechanisms/indicators’ is also a somewhat general longtermist/governance question. Tractability is moderate: one can operationalise partial answers via historical/political-economy studies of path dependence, empirical work on institutional irreversibility, technical analyses of AI deployment/standard-setting dynamics, and leading indicators (e.g., concentration of compute/power, hard-to-reverse infrastructure, binding treaties/constitutional changes, widespread adoption of rigid automated enforcement), but forecasting timing relative to ‘moral deliberation capacity’ remains difficult and model-dependent. Clarity is good but not crisp: ‘lock-in’, ‘reflection and bargaining mature’, and ‘irreversible commitments’ need sharper definitions and scope boundaries to be directly researchable. Decision hook is strong and explicitly stated (if lock-in tends to come early, prioritize early interventions). Dead weight is low: the context sentence directly motivates the question without redundant restatement.
title: Lock-in timing relative to moral deliberation capacity
